channel.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
channel.description:
Hi everyone :D This is my first post, so I had better introduce myself :D. My name is Tim Groeneveld, I live in Auzzie Land, and when I am not schooling or surfing with my friends, I work on my Linux distribution @ www.aegeanlinux.org :D So, now that you know all about me, let me introduce you to a project which I am trying to gather some interest about :D The code name of this beast is " [b]Lithium[/b] ", and it is a programming language! Here is a (sort of) example of the [current] syntax: [code]# # When you see this, it is a comment # the compiler should ignore this!!! # sub main () { $tim="Asdasdasdasadasd$dsf"; print "Hello World!\n"; #this is a mistake? print "Hello Aegean!\n"; }[/code] Basically, you run this source through a program called [b]compile[/b] (yes, it needs a better name :P), and it will output about 3 files. These files are: [ul][li]CMakeLists.txt[/li] [li][b]program_name[/b].cpp[/li][/ul] here is an example of running compile on a "Hello World" project:
tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] ./compile -c=project1.proj[/b] ==> Trying to convert the (project1.proj) project to C++ ... ==> Project is: Project One 1.00 ==> Programs to compile are: helloworld ==> Libraries to compile are: --> Will now try to build helloworld --> File program1.tssl ==> tocpp( "program1.tssl", "helloworld" ); ==> makeCPP( "", "$map" ); ==> Creating helloworld.cpp ==> makecmake(); tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] cmake .[/b] -- Configuring done -- Generating done -- Build files have been written to: /home/tim/tssl tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] make[/b] Scanning dependencies of target helloworld [100%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/helloworld.dir/helloworld.o Linking CXX executable helloworld [100%] Built target helloworld tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] ./helloworld[/b] Hello World! Hello Aegean!
through the whole process it turns the source file (shown above in the syntax example above) and turns it into a cpp file:
tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] cat helloworld.cpp[/b] // // File generated by TSSL (Mon Dec 25 14:38:39 EST 2006) // #include #include using namespace std; int main() { printf ( "Hello World!\n" ); printf ( "Hello Aegean!\n" ); }
The only needed apps for this to work in Linux are: [ul][li]perl[/li] [li]g++ (From GCC, the GNU Compiler Collection) [[i]others may work, this however, is untested[/i]][/li] [li]cmake [b]or[/b] autotools (autoconf, automake, aclocal etc) [[i]cmake is tested more often by me, and it works on Windows better, so I suggest cmake :D[/i]][/li][/ul] That is about it at the moment, it is still in development, and at the moment, it can only do "Hello World"'s, but I am now working on adding string support. If you want to give it a shot, you can check it out of SVN @ http://www.timg.ws:81/tssl/ Note: It should work on Windows without any issues, however, this is untested :D I am really interested in finding people who want to help with the development of Lithium, so if you are interested, PM me :D ~ Tim (P.S. I post alot of dev news on my site @ http://www.timg.ws)

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

no no, im not talking about published apis or anything. I certainly have some code I reuse in alot of my programs, generic code to do certian tasks I find myself doing alot. SOme of these libraries find their way into the open domain but I really dont think you should be writing a language to do common tasks easily. Apis give you much more flexibility (another reason developers have their own is they like to handle things such as files different, by implementing such things as callbacks//visitor patterns for ‘chunks’ split up by their own handlers etc). But its just a dev preferance, we have them to make our life easier, not to give around.

thou I havent used boost or looked at it, it could be something like that. FOr java some of the jakarta commons stuff would fall into place here.

Read full topic

maintainability? Sounds like you should just make some utility methods and share them out, vast numbers of programmers maintain their own little util packages for doing quick small projects.

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

Mopman:

Please just make it compile properly rather than generating C++ code, please please. It’s such a dirty idea.

That would take a huge amount of time, and would need a team bigger then just me But then again, if you are willing

~ Tim

P.S. To be honest, I quite like the idea

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

Silver Lining:

Hmmm… I’m not sure if this is what it actually does

Well, put simply, when you compile Java programs, it compiles into byte code, when you “compile” a Lithium program, it really converts the program into C++ source, which can be optimized to run on the operating system you are compiling the C++ code on

Silver Lining:

but here’s a suggestion: Make it have a special format (".lit" for example) and it compiles on runtime.

Well, that would be not only a lot harder to do, but also slower, and to be honest completely out of my reach

Plus, making C++ code is faster then with binary code

~ Tim

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

[quote=“TimG, post:9, topic:39104”][quote author=Silver Lining link=topic=55007.msg689171#msg689171 date=1167196558]
[…], I’m going to guess that you are going to have problems on optimization of the generated code.
[/quote]

Yes, this is probebly try, what I will say though is this: when you program with languages such as Java, Perl or PHP, they need to go through an interpreter/virtual machine (… OK, so Java is a bit different, but still :P). The cool thing about Lithium’s C++ output is, that even though it might not be as optimized as if you had written it all by your self, it will still have the positive of being in C++ in the first place, and programming code in C++ in Windows and Linux are very different, for example the way you code sockets etc. Lithium will completely remove the need for writing two different peices of code for Linux / Windows. When you code in Lithium, Lithium will output the best code for your computer and your operating system.

Well, that is the aim at least

~ Tim[/quote]Hmmm… I’m not sure if this is what it actually does, but here’s a suggestion: Make it have a special format (".lit" for example) and it compiles on runtime.

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

Silver Lining:

[…], I’m going to guess that you are going to have problems on optimization of the generated code.

Yes, this is probebly try, what I will say though is this: when you program with languages such as Java, Perl or PHP, they need to go through an interpreter/virtual machine (… OK, so Java is a bit different, but still :P). The cool thing about Lithium’s C++ output is, that even though it might not be as optimized as if you had written it all by your self, it will still have the positive of being in C++ in the first place, and programming code in C++ in Windows and Linux are very different, for example the way you code sockets etc. Lithium will completely remove the need for writing two different peices of code for Linux / Windows. When you code in Lithium, Lithium will output the best code for your computer and your operating system.

Well, that is the aim at least

~ Tim

P.S. Just for those who are interested, in the next two days I should be able to output code from this lithium source :

sub main {
declare ($tim, string);
$tim = "Hello World";
print($tim . "\n");
}

Not only that, but if’s (only basic if’s :P) are almost working too

I think that Lithium is begining to become really cool, and I would love to take this oppertunity to say thank you in advanced to anyone who will comment on Lithium’s syntax, report bugs and even submit patches to Lithium.

~ Tim

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

I vote that it’s a good idea. Personally, I’d love a extremely functional language that’d generate good C++ code. However, I’m going to guess that you are going to have problems on optimization of the generated code.

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

Freddy1990:

Meh, might as well learn c++

I am aiming to make it possible to open a file each new line until the end of the file in about this many lines:

sub main() { open (ID, "file.txt"); while(<ID>) { print ($_); } } close(ID);
much like you do in perl, I can tell you now, the C++ output of those 6 lines will be about > 15 lines, the whole aim of Lithium is to make it EASY.

Freddy1990:

Meh, might as well learn c++

Well, if that is how you feel :D. No one is forcing you to use another language. BUT, this could actually be a good way of teaching people, especially in the first stages, how to program in C++, because already it outputs perfect C++ source

There are roughly 100 languages existing in this computer world of ours, some are just for fun, some for a challenge. I realize I am adding to this language “glut”, but I think that coding up this language has something really unique to it. An ideal if you wish.

Well, tell me what you think, I am always open for opinion.

~ Tim

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

On another topic

if people are complaining about slow code, then you should aim for asm

Well, it is pretty easy to make an outputter ( there is one that generates code for C++, I am trying to get one for C# too ) why don’t you make one

Of course, I know that the chances that you would are very small for one of the following, which you may take your pick:

  1. ASM is not very portable, code that you write for Windows may not work in Linux
  2. Have you ever tried to write an UI in ASM for Windows
  3. Have you ever tried to write an UI in ASM for Linux, talk about starting a project!
  4. it is not worth the time that you would code for.

that being said, Lithium will soon support inline ASM

~ Tim[br][size=1]Posted on: December 26, 2006, 12:09:22 AM[/size][hr]For all those interested, I have just opened a website for Lithium over at http://lithium.timg.ws, it is only temporary for the moment, but it is cool to have a place where all Lithium d00ds can talk to each other and stuff.
So…
http://lithium.timg.ws (Main Site)
http://forum.lithium.timg.ws (Forum)

Let’s make this the best language to have yet to roam this planet of ours! I think a language such as this has some awesome potential!

~ Tim

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @Jorsa Jorsa
item.description:
@Jorsa wrote:

this would probably very good for people who want to learn C++
i will help by the way

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

On another topic

it shouldnt have to make it into c++

What language should it be in?

The aim of doing it like this, is so that you can write code, in a half decent language, and then make it output in a fast language.

Many people complain about VisualBasic being slow, and C++ being too hard to program in, so by being able to code in a language that outputs C++ code, no one can complain about the code being slow!

~ Tim

Read full topic

item.title: [Lithium] My programming languge
item.dc:creator: @TimG TimG
item.description:
@TimG wrote:

Hi everyone

This is my first post, so I had better introduce myself :D. My name is Tim Groeneveld, I live in Auzzie Land, and when I am not schooling or surfing with my friends, I work on my Linux distribution @ www.aegeanlinux.org

So, now that you know all about me, let me introduce you to a project which I am trying to gather some interest about

The code name of this beast is " Lithium ", and it is a programming language!

Here is a (sort of) example of the [current] syntax:

[code]#

When you see this, it is a comment

the compiler should ignore this!!!

sub main () {
$tim=“Asdasdasdasadasd$dsf”;

        print "Hello World!\n"; #this is a mistake?
                                            print "Hello Aegean!\n";

}[/code]

Basically, you run this source through a program called compile (yes, it needs a better name :P), and it will output about 3 files.

These files are:

[ul][li]CMakeLists.txt[/li]
[li]program_name.cpp[/li][/ul]

here is an example of running compile on a “Hello World” project:

tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] ./compile -c=project1.proj[/b] ==> Trying to convert the (project1.proj) project to C++ ... ==> Project is: Project One 1.00 ==> Programs to compile are: helloworld ==> Libraries to compile are: --> Will now try to build helloworld --> File program1.tssl ==> tocpp( "program1.tssl", "helloworld" ); ==> makeCPP( "", "$map" ); ==> Creating helloworld.cpp ==> makecmake(); tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] cmake .[/b] -- Configuring done -- Generating done -- Build files have been written to: /home/tim/tssl tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] make[/b] Scanning dependencies of target helloworld [100%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/helloworld.dir/helloworld.o Linking CXX executable helloworld [100%] Built target helloworld tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] ./helloworld[/b] Hello World! Hello Aegean!

through the whole process it turns the source file (shown above in the syntax example above) and turns it into a cpp file:

tim@aegeanlinux:~/tssl$[b] cat helloworld.cpp[/b] // // File generated by TSSL (Mon Dec 25 14:38:39 EST 2006) //

#include
#include
using namespace std;

int main() {

    printf ( "Hello World!\n" );
    printf ( "Hello Aegean!\n" );

}

The only needed apps for this to work in Linux are:

[ul][li]perl[/li]
[li]g++ (From GCC, the GNU Compiler Collection) [others may work, this however, is untested][/li]
[li]cmake or autotools (autoconf, automake, aclocal etc) [cmake is tested more often by me, and it works on Windows better, so I suggest cmake ][/li][/ul]

That is about it at the moment, it is still in development, and at the moment, it can only do “Hello World”'s, but I am now working on adding string support.

If you want to give it a shot, you can check it out of SVN @ http://www.timg.ws:81/tssl/

Note: It should work on Windows without any issues, however, this is untested

I am really interested in finding people who want to help with the development of Lithium, so if you are interested, PM me

~ Tim

(P.S. I post alot of dev news on my site @ http://www.timg.ws)

Read full topic
